Cory Joseph  I know we‚Äôre tanking but he very much did cost us a win. That and he‚Äôs taking a lot of minutes when we got Saben Lee who‚Äôs just earned more minutes with how well he‚Äôs played

This is a bit off the beaten path, but 2nd round pick Saben Lee has actually looked like he will carve out a long NBA career as a solid backup PG in the mold of Ish Smith.  His stats are nothing phenomenal, but he has a feel for the game and tenacity in getting into the paint/defending that is really impressive.
Cory Joseph and Saben Lee

Eh, it‚Äôs not rude to say that about a team that basically nobody other than devoted fans keeps track of. Well, for one Saddiq Bey is easily one of the top-5 rookies in this year‚Äôs draft class and is arguably the second best three point shooter in it after Haliburton, so that‚Äôs something pretty much every Pistons fan is excited about. Isaiah Stewart has been pretty exciting to watch for us as well because of his defensive-minded and aggressive style of play, which is pretty much the definition of Pistons basketball, he also shown flashes of outside shooting which would make him a really nice building block moving forward, oh and he‚Äôs 19 years old so he‚Äôll have plenty of time to develop here. Hayes doesn‚Äôt look like much just yet, but he‚Äôs also nineteen, is already a decent playmaker, has good size and plenty of potential. We also have a bunch of young players who have a good chance to help the team in long term, like Diallo, Saben Lee and Josh Jackson(who is a Detroit native and has been playing his heart out for us) and a bunch of cheap guys that we took a flyer on who try their best to prove their worth as NBA players(DSJ, Cook, Okafor, also Josh Jackson is in this category as well), never mind Grant proving himself as an All-Star candidate level of player. Also for the first time since 2003 we have a good chance of getting a high pick in the next draft which already looks quite promising. Obviously it‚Äôs not the same as having Sexland and Allen as far as young cores and concerned, but Garland and Sexton weren‚Äôt exactly spectacular their first year either, were they? So yeah, for the first time in forever Pistons have a clear direction and a definitive young group of players to build with and it‚Äôs quite nice to watch for the franchise that‚Äôs been suffering through mediocrity for the last 13 years. We‚Äôre in a rebuild right now, but I‚Äôd argue watching this team has been the most fun I‚Äôve had as a Pistons fan since what feels like forever.
Saddiq bey, Isaiah Stewart, and saben lee. Killians been injured but he‚Äôs shown flashes of being a great defender and excellent passer. Not to mention whoever we take in the upcoming draft.

**Killian Hayes** - started off slow, has looked like he has a much better pulse on our offensive movement since returning two games ago but still isn't scoring much. Really wish his success hadn't been tied to everyone's opinion of Kevin O'Connor because he's an extremely talented rookie who's been fine for what he was advertised, but because he isn't running away with RotY he's already been labeled a bust by some  **Isaiah Stewart** - was a fan favorite from day 1 for his hustle, but now his skill is starting to shine through and it's really exciting. He has shot 42% from deep (on limited attempts) and is above 50% from 10-16ft. His defensive hustle is insane (I believe he's leading rookies in Blocks per game) and he's a great offensive rebounder. He'll be fun to watch for a long time.  **Saddiq Bey** - came in as an NBA ready shooter (as advertised) but has shown a bit more ability than even that. He's put together a few moves with his back to the basket, can create his own 3 in a way that looks suspiciously identical to Wayne Ellington, and has put the ball on the floor as well. If he becomes a playmaker as well as a shooter, he should be a future all star.  **Saben Lee** - Isn't a revelation or anything but he looks like he'll last in the league which is pretty cool for a 2nd rounder. You can tell he's not comfortable with his shot but his ability to get to the rim and get fouled (or make the extra pass) has allowed him to stay on the floor. He also came very close to posterizing Vucevic so that was fun.  .  All in all, a pretty solid but VERY productive draft for Weaver's first year as GM. The future is exciting in Detroit.

Bey and Beef Stew both look like they're gonna be solid NBA players for a long time. Bey especially has been so nice  Killian just came back from injury and played his 9th game. Looks timid out there still and struggles to score but the defense looks good and his passing looks like it could be elite (see: lob to Diallo tonight)  Second rounder Saben Lee is going to make a great bench PG  Overall I think Weaver hit a solid triple in his first ever draft as our GM and has potential to be an all timer if Killian pans out as advertised

[Pistons youth movement is genuinely exciting](https://twitter.com/RedAlternates/status/1387929113252405248?s=20):  - They have a bonafide interior threat big who covers a crazy amount of space on defense and is showing some 3pt shooting chopps in Stewart (19yo)  - They have a sharpshooting wing with great awareness and on ball D who is showing some ability to take the ball to the hoop and use his strength to finish in Bey (22yo)  - They have a stellar passing PG with incredible vision and great on-ball and help D in Killian (19yo)  - They have a raw project with Siakim-esque upside in Sekou (20yo)  - They have an athletic, sharpshooting bench sparkplug with HoF tier hair in Frank Jackson (22yo)  - And they have two athletic, multi-tool bench wings who play hard nosed defense in Josh Jackson (24yo) and Hamidou Diallo (22yo)  That's 6 players 22 or younger who could have lasting roles in Weaver's restoration (4 of whom are more or less locks) without counting Saben Lee or our 2021 pick. For context, before the moratorium lifted last fall, the only player on the team under 22yo was Sekou. Just an insane transformation in only 6 months.

OKC has the best player in Shai, Dort is really good, and obviously a ton of picks.  However, I believe the Pistons have the better overall prospects and potential/fit as a team. Bey and Stewart already proved as rookies that they are very valuable players in the modern NBA. Killian Hayes still has a ton of potential. Obviously Cade coming in is a great prospect. He could be a superstar very soon. Even Sekou is still an unknown at still 20 years old. Then you throw in Saben Lee who surprised as a 2nd round point guard, and 3 second round picks this year (37, 42, 52) which could be packaged along with a player to move back into the first, this Pistons have quite a collection of solid young players. Plus Jerami Grant is the best of both teams veterans, and fits perfectly with the young core.   So basically at this time I'd say the Pistons will be better sooner. Now this can obviously change if Cade busts, the Pistons rookies from last year don't really improve at all, the Thunder hit on a few draft picks, package them for a legit star, or outright win the lottery, Poku actually becomes a good/great player, or if there are injuries, etc.

You‚Äôd be at 12 roster spots with picks 2, 23, 24, plus three second rounders, which obviously does not work.

Appreciate the work put into this. It‚Äôs a very well written and organized oc. And I agree JT‚Äôs next step would ideally be developing his playmaking.  I do struggle with what/how much to take from the stats given where certain other players are ranked. JT posts up twice a game so didn‚Äôt look into that one too much but the others all had some results that made me hesitant to put too much weight in them as a proxy for playmaking.  Luka‚Äôs tied with Dame for 20th highest assist% off drives (over 10 drives per game). Jaylen‚Äôs 24th. Love JB but his playmaking‚Äôs nowhere near theirs. Saben Lee, Kemba, Delon Wright, and Fultz rank 4th, 12th, 15th, and 17th and they all, plus Rozier, also outrank Doncic in pass% off drives (Harden‚Äôs 27th of 56th in that one, just above Siakam). Jokic isn‚Äôt top 10 in potential assists. Schroder‚Äôs ahead of Steph and .1 behind Jrue, closer than Jrue is to any of the 28 guys ahead of him. D‚ÄôLo‚Äôs assist% is better than the majority of guys with over 25 usg% including Giannis, Ja, Steph, DeMar and Shai.   Other metrics put JT in a better light but not sure how much to take from them either. These from Bball index were from the end of april so might‚Äôve changed a bit but that‚Äôs most of the season still. Of nba starting forwards, he was 10th in pass creation volume, 6th in pass creation quality, 1st in scoring gravity, 9th in playmaker rating, 7th in passes made, and 14th in assists per game. On his team, he was 1st in pass frequency, 2nd in passes per game, 3rd in assists per game, 3rd in pass creation volume, and 2nd in playmaker rating.   Info and definitions for above stats at https://www.bball-index.com/glossary/

Our backcourt was a mess. Easily the worst backcourt in the league. Revolving door of players. Killian hayes had a weird season due to first no offseason then getting injured. But he def showed flashes of what he‚Äôs capable of, and some of his best games playing side by side with saben lee, another pg.   Passing is great already and will probably be his best skill always. His pick and roll passing is good and his defense is already solid as well. It‚Äôs great cause a pairing of him and Cade at guard will be so large. Also, he‚Äôs a good rebounder for a guard.   Where he needs most work is in scoring. If he can improve his shooting numbers it‚Äôll benefit him a lot. Also, he‚Äôs not the best driver last season as he clearly favored his left hand. Also, in pick and roll he needs to be more aggressive in driving the ball. I think the coaches emphasized that and he improved a little bit towards the end last year, but there were still some times where he would go off a screen and drive and then back up from the paint looking to pass instead of just driving and scoring.   Overall, I‚Äôm excited to watch him cause he‚Äôs a fun player for sure. I think hell benefit playing with someone like Cade, which will also force him to improve his other skills in order to successfully play off ball with him. He‚Äôs stated multiple times last season he loved playing with another pg on the court so I‚Äôm excited to see him grow

The more I thought about it I think gap between Grant and Simmons is bigger than I was giving Ben credit for earlier. Grant turns 28 in March, his numbers are massively inflated and still aren‚Äôt too impressive, and he‚Äôs probably near his peak. His trade value is likely never going to be higher than it is right now, but he‚Äôs still nowhere near as good as Simmons. If the Pistons are serious about acquiring him, they will need to be open up to letting go of Bey because it‚Äôs doubtful Morey makes the trade without him.   But I was thinking about Hayes and Stewart when I wrote that. Hayes makes sense as we really need a facilitator, but he‚Äôs been awful so far so I doubt Morey wants him. Stewart doesn‚Äôt really make sense with Embiid and has been underwhelming this season. I think it was always a deep draft. A lot of guys have came in and helped their teams, even some late picks second rounders.   Pritchard has been great for the Celtics. Theo Maledon has looked very good. Xavier Tillman and Desmond Bane are effective rotation players and spot starters for a .500 team. Immanuel Quickley looks like he's gonna be a very good player. Isaiah Joe from Philly is still very raw but when they needed a shooter to insert into the lineup he played generally well.   And then I think there's quite a couple more second rounders who will become solid rotation players. Saben Lee has had some good flashes for Detroit, Paul Reed is tearing up the  G League for Philly.   All of those guys picked 20+, and then add on Wiseman, Patrick Williams, Lamelo, Halibuton with all-star potential and then Bey, Achiuwa, Maxey from non-lottery picks showing future starter ability. It's a good draft, and there's always going to be late bloomers as well
